Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Emergency Funding for Repair of the Bermuda Institute of Ocean Sciences Tudor Hill Marine Atmospheric Observatory
Award.AbstractNarration:
The marine troposphere plays important roles in the global geochemical cycles of many elements, in the global distribution of organic compounds, nutrients, microbes and pollutants, and in the global radiation budget. The ability to observe and sample gases, aerosol and precipitation in the marine boundary layer is central to providing a better understanding of these processes. By virtue of its location in the western North Atlantic Ocean, Bermuda has been a key location for numerous field studies of the marine troposphere. A marine atmospheric observatory, consisting of a 23-m high atmospheric sampling tower and site laboratories, was first established at Tudor Hill, Bermuda, in 1987 as part of the NSF-funded Atmosphere Ocean Chemistry Experiment. NSF support, the Tudor Hill tower and site laboratories were repaired and refitted in 2003, and have since been operated and maintained as a community research facility. Unfortunately, during the passage of Hurricane Gonzalo, a category 2 storm when it made landfall over Bermuda on 17-18 October 2014, the tower was damaged beyond repair. This award will enable the tower to be replaced to ensure that the research activities at the facility will continue.

This project is expected to make significant educational contributions at a number of levels, including undergraduate education opportunities through the NSF-funded Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) program at the Bermuda Institute of Ocean Sciences (BIOS), through other courses taught at BIOS, and by the inclusion of postgraduate students in external scientific research activities. The Tudor Hill facility will continue to feature in BIOS public outreach activities, public lectures, weekly tours, and the annual open-house day.

The Tudor Hill Atmospheric Observatory is currently funded to operate through to August, 2017. Through this award, the destroyed tower will be replaced so that these operations can continue. Presently the facility hosts long-term measurement activities in support of research and monitoring being conducted by a number of federal agencies and universities. Additionally, sampling activities for one NSF-funded project are due to commence later in 2015 and four additional prospective projects which would make use of the facility are currently awaiting funding decisions. Since NSF support commenced in 2003, research conducted at the facility to date has substantively contributed to at least 25 published peer-reviewed papers and to numerous presentations at US and international conferences. The facility has also been utilized as a critical mid-oceanic location for monitoring greenhouse gases, ozone and air column properties through the activities of NOAA and NASA. Collectively, these efforts have contributed to a better understanding of the biogeochemical and physical processes in the marine atmosphere. The continued operation and maintenance of the Tudor Hill site will facilitate research concerning the chemistry and physics of the marine troposphere and ocean-atmosphere exchange processes - topics that are central to international research initiatives such as IGAC, SOLAS and GEOTRACES. Findings from such studies can be expected to improve prediction and mitigation of the effects of anticipated future climatic and environmental change. In a regional context, the Tudor Hill facility will complement ongoing time-series research in the Sargasso Sea, including Hydrostation S and the Bermuda Atlantic Time Series Station..

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview.  The marine atmosphere plays a central role in the global biogeochemical cycles of organic and inorganic compounds including nutrients and pollutants, oxidation processes, the distributions of microbes, and earth's radiation balance and climate.  Central to improving our understanding of these processes is the ability to reliably characterize physical and chemical properties of marine air.  By virtue of its location in the western North Atlantic Ocean, Bermuda is alternately influenced by air and associated emission products flowing from North America, northern Africa and Europe, and the central North Atlantic region.  Because it provides opportunities to characterize aspects of these distinct air-mass types at a single open-ocean location, numerous investigations of the marine atmosphere have been conducted on Bermuda.  To facilitate such studies, a marine atmospheric observatory consisting of a 23-m high sampling tower and on-site laboratories was established at Tudor Hill, Bermuda, in 1987 as part of the NSF-funded Atmosphere Ocean Chemistry Experiment (AEROCE).  With support from NSF's Chemical Oceanography and Atmopheric Chemistry Programs, the Tudor Hill tower and laboratories were renovated in 2003 and have since been maintained and operated as a community research facility by the Bermuda Institute of Ocean Sciences (BIOS).  During the passage of Hurricane Gonzalo on 17-18 October 2014, the tower suffered a catastrophic failure and collapsed.  This project funded the erection of a replacement tower at Tudor Hill thereby enabling resumption of research activies at the facility.

Intellectual Merit.  Prior to the tower's collapse, the Tudor Hill Atmospheric Observatory hosted research efforts conducted by both universities and federal agencies that involved long-term measurements of greenhouse gases, ozone, and physcial properties of the air column as well as shorter-term intensive campaigns.  As widely reported in many papers published in scientific journals and presented at scientic conferences, results of these investigations have contributed substantively to our knowledge of biogeochemical and physical processes in marine air.  Following loss of the tower, these ongoing research efforts at Tudor Hill were either suspended or the measurement protocols had to be modified substantially to the detriment of subsequent data quality.  In addition, one NSF-funded project at Tudor Hill was scheduled to commense shortly after the tower collapsed and several other proposed projects were awaiting funding decisions.  Replacement of the tower allowed resumption of the long-term measurement programs using established protocols, initiaiton of pending projects, and continuation of the ability to support future campaigns thereby facilitating ongoing progress in the field.

Broader Impacts.  Results of studies hosted by the observatory are directly relevant to and build on a number of national and international programs investigating interrelated impacts of marine and anthropogenic emissions on air quality, climate, and feedbacks on the ocean.  Of particular relevance are the Surface Ocean Lower Atmosphere Study and the International Global Atmospheric Chemistry Project under the auspices of the International Geosphere-Biosphere Programme, NASA's Tropospheric Chemistry and Radiation Sciences Programs, NOAA's Climate and Global Change Program, and DOE's Atmospheric Chemistry Program and Scientific Discovery through Advanced Computing.  Results generated at the observatory also complement time-series research at regional hydrostations.  The facility provides opportunities for the education and ongoing professional development of users (both students and professional researchers) including participants in the NSF-funded Research Experience for Undergraduates Program at BIOS.  The Tudor Hill Atmospheric Observatory and associated research activities are featured in BIOS public outreach activities including public lectures, articles in local magezines, weekly tours, and annual open houses.
